gmd:definition.gco:CharacterString: Documentation of taxonomic sources, procedures, and treatments

gmd:rule.gco:CharacterString: New Metadata section as a class to MD_Identification

gmd:rationale.gco:CharacterString: The set of data elements contained within this class element represents an attempt to provide better documentation of taxonomic sources, procedures, and treatments.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: A Strategic and Science-Based Framework for Management of Invasive Annual Grasses in the Sagebrush Biome - Cores Only

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
File-based data available at: https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/676d8256d34e3ce2f6084e91
In the last 20 years, the North American sagebrush biome has lost over 500 000 ha of intact and largely intact sagebrush plant communities on an annual basis. Much of this loss has been associated with expansion and infilling of invasive annual grasses (IAGs). These species are highly competitive against native perennial grasses in disturbed environments, and create fuel conditions that increase both the likelihood of fire ignition and the ease of wildfire spread across large landscapes. Given the current rate of IAG expansion in both burned and unburned rangelands, we propose a range-wide paradigm shift from opportunistic and reactive management, to a framework that spatially prioritizes maintenance of largely intact, uninvaded areas and improvement of invaded habitats in strategic locations. We created a framework accompanied by biome-wide priority maps using geospatial overlays that target areas to MAINTAIN large, uninvaded areas as natural resource anchors through activities to prevent IAGs, IMPROVE areas where management success in restoring large, intact landscapes is most likely, and CONTAIN IAG infestations where necessary. We then offer three case studies to illustrate the use of these concepts and map products at multiple scales. Our map products operate at the biome scale using regional data sources and additional data sources will be needed to inform local conservation planning. However, the basic strategic management principles of (1) maintaining the intact and uninvaded areas that we can least afford to lose to IAGs, (2) improving areas where we have a reasonable likelihood of restoration success, and (3) containing problems where we must, are timely, relevant, and scalable from the biome to local levels.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Boyd, Chad S., Megan K. Creutzburg, Alexander V. Kumar, Joseph T. Smith, Kevin E. Doherty, Brian A. Mealor, John B. Bradford et al. "A strategic and science-based framework for management of invasive annual grasses in the Sagebrush Biome." Rangeland Ecology & Management 97 (2024): 61-72.

While the Service makes every reasonable effort to ensure the accuracy and completeness of data provided for distribution, it may not have the necessary accuracy or completeness required for every possible intended use. The Service recommends that data users consult the associated metadata record to understand the quality and possible limitations of the data. The Service creates metadata records in accordance with the standards endorsed by the Federal Geographic Data Committee. As a result of the above considerations, the Service gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of the data. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data in a manner consistent with the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the Service, no warranty, expressed or implied, is made regarding the utility of the data on another system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This applies to the use of the data both alone and in aggregate with other data and information.

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Retrieved from the Integrated Taxonomic Information System on-line database, https://www.itis.gov.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Our study area was defined by the US portion of the sagebrush biome (3.0 million km2) including portions of 13 western states (Jeffries and Finn, 2019; Fig. 1). Sagebrush rangelands were identified using the Doherty et al. (2022b) sagebrush ecological integrity (SEI) model, which excluded non-rangelands (forests, lakes, urban areas, cropland, barren areas, and alpine tundra grasslands).

We developed models and produced continuous priority maps representing three strategic IAG management priorities using the best available spatial data across the biome: MAINTAIN (where IAGs are currently largely absent and biotic integrity is most at risk), IMPROVE (where low to moderate IAG reduction is needed and most likely to succeed), and CONTAIN (relatively intractable and established IAG problems with a high likelihood of spread).

The MAINTAIN priority map identified minimally-invaded areas with high ecological integrity that were at high risk of IAGs. We selected three inputs: 1) current annual herbaceous cover, 2) invasion risk, and 3) potential loss of ecological integrity resulting from a hypothetical increase in IAGs. Annual herbaceous cover was derived by averaging estimates of annual forb and grass cover (AFG) for the most recent 4 years (2019–2022) from the Rangeland Analysis Platform (hereafter RAP; Jones et al., 2018; Allred et al., 2021). Our weighting curve placed the highest weight (1) at 0% cover, with weight decreasing linearly to 0 at 15% cover (Fig. 3). AFG cover 15% or greater was set to 0. To quantify risk of annual grass invasion we used INHABIT species distribution maps for cheatgrass (Bromus tectorum), red brome (B. rubens), Japanese brome (B. japonicus), ventenata (Ventenata dubia), and medusahead (Taeniatherum caput-medusae) (Jarnevich et al. 2023a, 2023b; Williams et al. 2023). Lastly, we derived an input from the continuous sagebrush ecological integrity (SEI) product from Doherty et al. (2022) to quantify sensitivity to a hypothetical increase in annual cover. We simulated a uniform increase in AFG of 15 percentage points across the biome (truncating values at 100%), re-calculated SEI, and determined the change in SEI from current values.

The IMPROVE priority map identified areas that could benefit from IAG treatment and where treatment would have a relatively high likelihood of success. We identified these areas by combining four inputs: 1) current annual herbaceous cover, 2) current perennial herbaceous cover, 3) abiotic resistance to IAGs, and 4) potential ecological integrity after successful treatment to remove IAGs. To estimate IAG cover, we used RAP AFG cover as described above. Our curve placed the minimum weight at 0% AFG cover and increased linearly up to 15% cover. AFG cover ≥ 15% was given a maximum value of 1. For perennial cover, we used RAP perennial forb and grass (PFG) cover estimates averaged over 2019-2022. We placed a weight of 0 on areas with <10% cover. For cover values ≥10%, we defined curves that peaked at intermediate values and then declined as perennial cover approached 100%. For the Great Plains, values increased linearly from 10% cover to 50% cover and then decreased linearly to 100%. For the rest of the biome, values increased linearly from 10% cover to 30% cover and then decreased linearly to 100%. Abiotic resistance was derived from recently published continuous resistance and resilience (R&R) spatial products (Schlaepfer and Bradford 2024; Schlaepfer et al. In Revision). We quantified the potential gains in ecological integrity from successful intervention with a metric derived from the SEI product from Doherty et al. (2022). Specifically, we quantified ecological integrity under a hypothetical elimination of IAGs by setting AFG cover to zero across the biome and recalculating the SEI (hereafter SEIAFG = 0).

CONTAIN areas were identified where management may need to adapt to a novel vegetation community dominated or co-dominated by IAGs. CONTAIN priority scores were derived by combining three inputs: annual herbaceous cover, perennial herbaceous cover, and abiotic resistance to IAGs. AFG cover from RAP was given a minimum weight of 0 from 0–15% cover with weights increasing linearly up to 60% cover. AFG cover ≥60% was given a maximum value of 1. PFG cover from RAP was given a maximum value at 0% cover and linearly decreased to 30% cover. Perennial cover ≥30% was given a minimum value of 0. Abiotic resistance was rescaled and inverted from [-1,1] to [1,0] to weight areas with low resistance more heavily, identifying areas where likelihood of successful restoration is low.

We combined the MAINTAIN, IMPROVE, and CONTAIN layers into a single map for display by calculating the maximum score among the three layers and assigning each pixel to the highest-scoring category. Because we deemed it inappropriate to prioritize areas with low overall scores, we classified pixels that fell into the MAINTAIN or IMPROVE categories, but had a priority score <0.5, into a fourth category that we call “Other”. In addition, to minimize working in areas with persistently low ecological integrity, we identified MAINTAIN and IMPROVE pixels that had been classified as ORA for the study duration (2001-2020) from Doherty et al. (2022), and placed them in the Other category. To display gradients of priority within the MAINTAIN and IMPROVE categories, we binned priority scores such that scores < 0.65 were low priority, scores between 0.65 - 0.8 were moderate priority, and scores >0.8 were high priority, where darker shades indicate higher priority (Fig. 4). Therefore, the overall priority maps include a categorical component (MAINTAIN, IMPROVE, CONTAIN, or Other) and a continuous component (priority level for MAINTAIN or IMPROVE).

Two versions of the final, combined priority map were produced – one displaying MAINTAIN, IMPROVE, and CONTAIN priorities across the sagebrush biome, and one displaying the same information, but masked to only show areas that we call “current and potential cores”.
